captions.text:
How to Pretend You’re a Real New Yorker.
There’s nothing wrong with being a tourist

in New York City. But if you want to blend
in, here’s what you need to know. You will

need A copy of The New York Times A copy of
the New York Post A quick stride Black clothes

A cell phone and an outsized ego. Step 1.
Start the day by scanning The New York Times

and reading the gossipy Page Six of the New
York Post. Forget USA Today – New Yorkers

only read that as a last resort. Step 2. Ditch
the map – it’s a dead giveaway! Get the

general lay of the land before you leave your
hotel, then only take the map out when you

can study it surreptitiously – like in a
bathroom. Step 3. Speaking of bathrooms, there

are hardly any public restrooms in New York,
so take advantage of “semi-public” bathrooms

in department stores, museums, cafes, and
restaurants. Step 4. Be provincial. If anyone

mentions anyplace in the country other than
Los Angeles, Miami, and Chicago, ignore them.

Pretend to know everything there is to know
about New York City. Make sure to reminisce

about the good old days when Time Square was
riddled with crime and porno shops. Step 5.

Never drive a car in the city. Take the subway,
a bus, or a cab—or better yet, walk. Step

6. Walk as fast as you can at all times, even
if you’re not in a hurry. Never stand on

the curb waiting for a light. Step off and
edge your way into the street until you can

cross. Step 7. Know how to give a cabbie directions:
New Yorkers never give an exact, number address.

They give the street and the cross streets
that border the block, like “50th between

5th and Madison!” H-o-u-s-t-o-n Street is
pronounced “How-stun,” not “Hyoo-stun.”

Step 8. Wear a lot of black, especially if
you’re a woman. It doesn’t matter if Manhattan

women are going to work, to a nightclub, or
to a two-year-old’s birthday party – it’s

always better in black, and it’s always
better to err on the side of dressy rather

than casual. If you must buy a souvenir “I
Heart New York” t-shirt, for goodness sake,

leave it in the bag. Don’t wear it until
you’re home. Step 9. Eat from the street.

No, not dumpsters – street vendors! Yeah,
it’s a little scary, but it’s also cheap,

convenient, and surprisingly good. And we
can’t remember the last person who died

from it. New York City honors its food vendors
with the annual Vendy Awards. Research who

won most recently and hit up their cart. Step
10. Eat in restaurants after 8 p.m. – before

that, they’re either empty or—horror of
horrors— patronized by families with small

children. Play it safe; have dinner at 9 and
drinks at 11. Step 11. Always be on your cell

phone or checking your Blackberry. Is it rude?
Yes. Is it the norm in New York City? Yes.

Step 12. Come back soon! You’re not nearly
as annoying now as you were when you arrived.

Did you know Two-thirds of New Yorkers polled
said that the holidays are the best time to
visit New York City.

title: How to Pretend You’re a Real New Yorker

comments.text:
YESSSSSSS!!!!!!!!! Full of wannabe phonies who are trying their best to 
pull off the whole "fake it til you make it" persona but they do it with a 
sense of superiority and entitlement, that's what makes it so repulsive. 
It's exhausting because it's mostly the nobodies who are trying the hardest 
and being the most obnoxious. The people who are already doing well are not 
as pretentious. It's one of the fakest cities I've been to and I've 
travelled to about 30 different cities in the States and around the world. 
And New Yorkers call LA folks phony. They are too but they are no where 
near as bad as the wannabe socialites and  wanna be fashionistas or wannabe 
wolf of wall street people in New York. And the locals are great but too 
many of them are kind of ratchet and ghetto. LA people are still warm and 
friendly and a lot more laid back. I've been here for 1.5 years and I'm 
leaving to head out west in a couple of months. I am literally counting 
down the days!! Can't wait to leave this filthy city!!

comments.author: Armando B.

comments.text:
As a New Yorker, we are used to tourists, so why blend in. I lived out west 
and while Cali is sunny and oregon and Washington beautiful, I would say 
the thing I like about ny is that we don't need to talk about diversity or 
lack thereof, just the tensions between different groups. NYC isn't just 
downtown manhattan but most New Yorkers refer to that part as the city, and 
everything else by the neighborhood. New York is one of them cities where 
you try to find your hustle, art or industry and hone it to the best of ur 
ability because there is a lot of competition. It's about innovation rather 
than the whole copy what everyone else is doing and nothing new. On the 
west it's like nobody has anything creative to offer that hasn't been done 
to death. Anyways that's off topic. When ur in ny just be u, the individual 
rather than the u, who tries to be someone else﻿
comments.author: Christopher Chenet

comments.author: Grisel Griselda

comments.text:
+Grisel Griselda I know this question isn't directed at me but I am moving 
out of the city in a few weeks and I am so happy about it!!! For me, I 
can't deal with the smell and the dirtiness and the daily chaos. Smelling 
human feces everyday and sitting next to mentally ill people on the trains 
and having rats run over my feet is an interesting experience but not the 
kind of longterm lifestyle for me. I like people and I like to do a lot of 
things but constantly being bombarded with people has just wore me out. 
Plus, I want to be around beautiful sceneries with gorgeous and calm 
landscapes now.  All the concrete and buildings were cool at first but now 
I'm seriously needing some beautiful trees and lakes and mountains around 
me and Central Park is not enough. I'm very extroverted but I am also 
introspective and I like to take time to myself to think, meditate, and 
clear my head. I find it to be bloody hell difficult to do that here in 
NYC. My apartment is too small and too expensive. The new apartment that I 
found out West is twice as big with a view of the water and the mountains 
and its half the price. And Im doing the same work I do out here but 
getting paid more money and the weather will be better. That being said, I 
had a great time here, it was fun while it lasted, but for me...NYC is like 
a summer fling, its exciting and passionate but we both know it isn't long 
term commitment material.

comments.author: ethan shum

comments.text:
That's because they are probably ripping you off. Street vendors love to 
rip off people who are not from NYC. The key is to just hand them the exact 
change and take your food and walk away. You shouldn't be paying no more 
than $7 for food and $2 for a drink. If you notice, they never have prices 
by the food. They do that on purpose because they know that out-of-towners 
don't know how much street food costs so they will ask, "How much is this?" 
And that's when the vendor will add a few extra dollars to the price and 
he'll rip you clean off!

comments.author: Chris Ray Gun

comments.text:
Know that we're not rude. NYC is simply very systematic and there are codes 
by which to live. 1) Learn to use your metro card, even if it means 
standing in viewing distance of someone using the machine. Holding up lines 
is annoying. 2) If you're going to stop to check your phone, pull to the 
sides of the streets towards the building and away from the road. 3) Walk 
as fast as you naturally can without jogging or straining yourself. That's 
literally all you need.
comments.author: Chris Ray Gun
